introduction:
In this lesson, we will learn how to make a good first impression when meeting new people. We will focus on basic greetings, introductions, and polite expressions.

Grammar Focus: Simple Present Tense: 'I am…', 'You are…', 'He/She is…'. Personal Pronouns: I, You, He, She, We, They. Possessive Adjectives: My, Your, His, Her.
presentation:
New Vocabulary & Phrases:

  • Hello / Hi - A friendly greeting.
  • Nice to meet you - A polite phrase used when meeting someone for the first time.
  • How are you? - A common way to ask about someone’s well-being.
  • I am... / My name is... - Ways to introduce yourself.
  • This is... - Used to introduce someone else.
  • Please - A polite word used when making a request.
  • Thank you - A polite way to show gratitude.
  • Goodbye / Bye - Words used when leaving.
  • Where are you from? - A question to ask about someone’s origin.
  • I’m from... - A way to tell where you are from.

Example Sentences: Hello, I’m Anna. Nice to meet you! How are you? – I’m good, thank you! This is my friend, John. Where are you from? – I’m from Spain. Goodbye! See you later!

data: Hello, Peter! Nice to meet you.
Hello, Peter! Nice to meet you.

conclusion:
Review:

  • Key expressions: Hello, Nice to meet you, How are you?, I am..., Where are you from?, Goodbye.
  • Grammar structures: Simple Present Tense, Personal Pronouns, Possessive Adjectives.

Example Dialogue:

A: Hello! I’m Mark.
B: Hi, Mark! I’m Lisa. Nice to meet you!
A: Nice to meet you, too. Where are you from?
B: I’m from Canada. And you?
A: I’m from the UK.
B: That’s nice! See you later.
A: Goodbye!

Questions to Reinforce Material:

  • How do you introduce yourself?
  • What do you say when you meet someone new?
  • How do you ask where someone is from?
  • What are polite words to use when talking to someone?

Homework:

Write a short dialogue (4-6 lines) where you introduce yourself to someone new. Include greetings, introductions, and a question about where they are from.
